results.title: Animals see in many ways. - Rev. ed.
results.creator_credit: Marjorie Bean, Norman Bean and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: This film illustrates the differences in the eyes of various animals, from the simple eyes of an insect to the complex eyes of a back-boned animal. It shows that the kind and position of an animal’s eyes are clues to the animal’s way of life. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Anna Karenina. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Basil Coleman, Donald Wilson and BBC Enterprises
results.brief_description: Anna Karenina after being married for ten years and moving in the highest aristocratic and political circles finds herself in a failing marriage. Believing herself to be vulnerable to temptation, she meets a man who is able to awaken a love that will prove tragic and fatal. Shot in Budapest, Hungary and England this BBC dramatisation brings to life Leo Tolstoy’s classic novel. Stars Nicola Pagett and Stuart Wilson.

results.title: Ankali means friend
results.brief_description: Ankali is part of Sydney’s Albion Street AIDS Centre. It is run by professional staff and 145 volunteer counsellors. The Ankali project has, since 1985, offered emotional support to people with AIDS. This film focuses on two volunteer counsellors, a psychologist and a teacher, and their clients.

results.title: Andy Hardy Series
results.brief_description: One of the most popular US series, the Hardy family first appeared in “A Family Affair” 1937 with Lionel Barrymore and Mickey Rooney as father and son. In 1938 “You’re Only Young Once” began the official series in the town of Carvel, with Rooney as Andy Hardy, typical American teenager, interested in girls and fast cars, Lewis Stone as James Judge Hardy, a stern but understanding father, Fay Holden as his “swell” mother, Cecilia Parker as Marian, his older sister striving to be a young lady, Sara Haden as Aunt Millie and Ann Rutherford as Polly, the girlfriend who was often neglected for other prospects but to whom Andy always returned. George B. Seitz directed most of the series. A testament to the series’ great appeal was the special Oscar given MGM “for its achievement in representing the American Way of Life.” MGM used the films to springboard young starlets such as Judy Garland, Lana Turner, Esther Williams, Kathryn Grayson and Donna Reed. The Hardy films serve as a reminder of an era in Hollywood and America that is long gone.

results.title: Animation legend Winsor McCay
results.creator_credit: Winsor McCay, Albert Miller, La Cinematheque Quebecoise Montreal (Quebec) Canada and Lumivision Corporation
results.brief_description: All ten of Winsor McCay’s films and fragments are on this compilation, transferred from the archive prints at Cinematheque Quebecoise. An important figure in the development of cinema, he developed a stage act at the beginning of this century that incorporated a series of “lightning sketches”, which in turn led to his creation of moving pictures.

results.title: Animation on 4. Vol. 02
results.brief_description: A compilation of award-winning animated short films commissioned by Channel 4 in Britain. “Screen play” (dir. Barry Purves) is a tale of doomed love played out on a model Japanese stage. “Abductress” (dir. Paul Vester) combines live action, grainy black and white documentary footage and drawn animation to explore the memories of people who claim to have been abducted by aliens. “The Village” (dir. Mark Baker) juxtaposes delightful storybook images of a traditional village with adult concerns about social behaviour. In “The Sound of music” (dir. Phil Mulloy) uncompromising black ink drawings flesh out an acerbic satire on modern city life. The relationship between rhythm and movement is explored through a seamless merging of the human form with music in “Triangle” (dir. Erica Russell). In “The Mill” (dir. Petra Freeman) a little girl is left to her own devices in an unwelcoming factory. “Secret joy of falling angels’ (dir. Simon Pummell) uses a sumptuous visual feast of mixed media - line drawings, still paintings and model work - to create a seductive, atmospheric abstraction. There is no explicit narrative, instead emotion and instinct guide the viewer through the film’s hypnotic, intertwined threads.

results.title: Animation greats!
results.creator_credit: Various and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A compilation from the National Film Board of Canada spanning 20 years with eight short animation works using a variety of animation techniques. “Special delivery”: Winner of the 1979 Academy Award for Best Animated Short this animation is about Alice and Ralph Phelps and their battle to solve the mystery of the dead mailman - a comic moral tale. “Getting started”: An animation about procrastination as our hero attempts to practice on the piano but is constantly distracted. “The Big Snit”: This award winning wacky film looks at two simultaneous conficts, the macrocosm of global nuclear war and the microcosm of a domestic quarrel and how each is resolved. “Get a job”: Follow the tribulations of a cartoon character, Bob Dog, as he hunts for a job. “The Cat came back”: Based on a century old folk song, Mr Johnson becomes increasingly manic as he tries and tries again to rid himself of a little yellow cat. “Juke Bar”: A Juke Box is deliverd to a cafe and the cockroaches that infest the place jump and jive all night inside the ‘Juke Bar’ only to become trapped and removed in the morning. “Blackfly”: A folk tune from 1949 about the prevalence of the black fly in northern Ontario brought to life through animation. “The Lump”: Using a fun technique of recycled objects and photos of people’s heads, this is the story of George; who although short and ugly, develops a lump on his head that has handsome human features which he uses for political gain - until corruption catches up with him. Some titles also available on VHS or 16mm [012927], [014401], [017344], [316221], [301087].

results.title: Animated motion. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: Grant Munro, Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In this second film, Norman McLaren presents the first three of the five categories of motion: constant, accelerated, and decelerated. Various types of acceleration and deceleration are demonstrated, and examples are shown of how these types of motion may be applied in regard to gesture, gravity, and perspective.

results.title: Animals: friends or food? [Widescreen] (D)
results.creator_credit: Jason Young, Kent Martin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A would-be farmer, Jason Young, and his partner take on an abandoned farm property, with the view to running a small hobby-farm, and horse-riding school. Whilst Julia attends to the horse-business Jason decides to experiment with raising an array of animals with a view to eating them, in order to bring himself closer to the processes of animal husbandry that so many have become immune to. Thus begins Jason’s year of discovery as he buys, bonds, feeds, tends and lovingly breeds the animals. At certain points when Jason is called upon to slaughter the animals he confronts the issues around meat eating, and is moved by the bonds he has formed with the various breeds. Although at times simplistic, this documentary nevertheless teases out the issues of the meat consumer industry, human-animal relationships and the ethical treatment of animals. Contains scenes of animal slaughter. Please note: some scenes may disturb.

results.title: Angus lost
results.creator_credit: Gary Templeton, John Sturner, Evergreen Productions and Firehouse Productions
results.brief_description: Angus is a very curious, clever Scottish terrier, whose curiosity gets him into a number of close scrapes. This is a live-action, non-verbal adaptation of Marjorie Flack’s classic book and is sure to delight audiences both young and old.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gary Templeton, John Sturner, Evergreen Productions and Firehouse Productions
